metadata.title: Supporting Information Mechanistic Study of the Reaction of Thiol-Containing Enzymes with a,b-Unsaturated Carbonyl Substrates by Computation and Chemoassays

Relative energies of computed potential energy surfaces according to Figure 1 .

Inhibition mechanisms, in which covalent bonds are formed, can formally be divided into two steps (see Scheme 1 of publication). [ 1 ] The first step consists of the formation of a non-covalent enzyme-inhibitor complex (EI) . Within this complex, the attacking enzyme moiety is oriented in such a way that the covalent bond (E-I) can be formed, e.g., by an attack of a nucleophilic center of the enzyme at the electrophilic center of the inhibitor. The resulting chemical reaction represents the second step of the overall inhibition. Within this step the bond formation is mainly influenced by enthalpic effects since all entropic contributions which are connected to the formation of the enzyme-inhibitor complex are already included in step 1. [ 2 ] Furthermore entropy effects are quite uniform for similar reactions and hence do not change the relative trends,
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: The present work focuses on the second step. In the present context it involves the formation of a covalent bond between a thiol residue (e.g. of the cysteine residue of the SARS-CoV M Pro ) and the electrophilic building block of the inhibitor. Models, which aim to describe this step in all details, have to account for the influence of the protein and the solvent environment. This can be achieved with QM/MM approaches which take enzyme and solvent explicitly into account. They are even able to describe effects like regio-or stereoselectivity of the inhibition process. [3] However, as
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: shown recently in investigations about the inhibition of papain-like proteases [1] valuable insights into the influence of the substitution pattern of the warhead are already possible from simpler models. These mimick all important parts of the considered system by truncated model compounds in combination with a continuum model like COSMO. [4] Only for the description of the regio-and the stereoselectivity of the inhibition process protein, solvent environments and those substituents of the inhibitor being responsible for the stability of the reversible enzyme-inhibitor complex have to be taken into account explicitly. However, the influence of substituents, which are directly attached to the electrophilic moiety and influence the inhibition due to electronic reasons, could already be explained by much easier models. Such models could even elucidate the dependency of the inhibition potency on the pH-value of the environment and the influence of the His moiety of the cysteine protease. [1] S3 These models approximate the cysteine residue by a methyl thiolate while the environment was modelled either by two water molecules (pK s ≈15) to mimic a low proton-donating ability of the environment or by two ammonium molecules (pK s ≈9.3)
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: to simulate a higher proton-donating ability. These explicit solvent molecules were employed in combination with the continuum model COSMO which accounts for the overall polarizability of the solvent and the protein environment. From the inhibitor only the electrophilic warhead and its directly attached substituents were taken into account. Information about the kinetics and thermodynamics of the irreversible step of the inhibition were obtained through potential energy surfaces of the inhibition process which were computed employing the B3LYP/TZVP//BLYP/TZVP level of theory.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Since such approaches are considerably less expensive than QM/MM computations they allowed a scan of a large number of substituents to test changes in the inhibition potencies of epoxides and aziridines. Such model calculations are also important to distinguish between influences of the enzyme environment and inherent effects resulting from the electronic structure of the inhibitor itself. That the prediction of the computations could be proven experimentally underlines the reliability of the simple approach. [1] To transfer such models to the situation in thiol containing enzymes reacting with etacrynic acid derivatives the following approximations were adopted (see Figure 2 of publication). The thiol containing residue of the enzyme is mimicked by methyl thiol.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Possible proton acceptor groups, (e.g. the histidine residue of the SARS-CoV M pro ) are assumed to play the role of the proton acceptor in the base catalyzed process. To evaluate the importance of the base catalysis such groups are modelled by an ammonia molecule which has been shown to be a good approximation. [1] This is shown by comparison between simpler QM [1,a,b] and more elaborated QM/MM [3a] approaches. The former used ammonium while the latter employed a histidine group.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: The similarity may result since its pKa value (9.3) is not too different from histidine residues in thiol proteases (pKa 8-9). [3] Additionally, to investigate the influence of the substitution pattern of the α,β-unsaturated carbonyl derivates on the reaction mechanisms we modelled the reactions of compounds 1-11 depicted in Figure 3 of the publication. A description of previous works is given in the paper.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Due to the strong dependence on the actual number of water molecules the computation of the activation energy for this complicated process is too tedious for the goal of the present work which wants to study the influence of various substitution patterns.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Furthermore, the computations had to take possible proton catalyzation effects into account and finally, one can assume that the actual course of the ketonization in solvents will differ from the ketonization in the active site of the enzyme since the narrowness of the active site does not allow complicated water bridges.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Nevertheless, since the corresponding barriers are similar or perhaps even higher than the barriers of the addition step the ketonization can be expected to influence the inhibition potency of a given inhibitor strongly.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: To take this into account we developed a model which estimates the inherent However, for physiological medium the enol should represent a stable intermediate.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: The final product of the base catalyzed ketonization is obtained by a proton transfer from a proton donor to C2. If both proton transfers are interchanged the reaction proceeds along the enol cation E + . This should also be the case in a quite acid environment. The influence of the substitution pattern of the Michael system on the ketonization should already be reflected in the relative energies of the enolate or the enol-cation. The actual environment will of course influence the reaction barriers between the single steps, however, considering the trends between the different substitution patterns this should average out.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: The necessary computations of the conceivable reactions steps started with a detailed investigation of the reaction of acrolein (1, see Figure 3 of publication) which represents the simplest systems. We first computed the reaction branch up to the enol form to study the possibility of a base catalysis. The model is sketched in Figure   2 of the publication together with a definition of the important internal degrees of freedom. For the accompanied S-C-bond formation the distance between the sulphur centre of methyl thiol and the C3 center of the inhibitor (r(S--C), see Figure 2 of the publication) is important. However, since the reaction is assumed to be base catalyzed the proton transfer from the thiol to the base has also to be taken into account. To describe this process also the distance between the sulphur and the proton of the ammonium (r(S--H), see Figure 2 of the publication) had to be varied.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Since it was unknown to which extent variations in both coordinates depend on each other, we computed two-dimensional potential energy surfaces ( The relative energies given from the computed potential energy surfaces are influenced by the possible hydrogen bonding networks between the various subsystems. The effects are minimized since solvent effects are partly taken into consideration by continuum approaches. However, the energies are still slightly biased towards those intermediates which are able to form strong hydrogen bonds.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: For the description of the ketonization the corresponding problems are even more severe.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Since we are only interested in trends arising from the substitution pattern it is necessary to compute relative energies without the influence of the network. A suitable reference for the all energy considerations is E 0 which represents the energy of the model system in which all reactants and all explicitly accounted solvent molecules are infinitely separated so that no hydrogen bonding network exists. Since the s-trans form is slightly lower in energy, E 0 is defined as:
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: The energies of the ammonia and of the ammonium ion are necessary for the comparison with the computed PES. Relative energies with respect to E 0 which also S6 do not account for the influence of the hydrogen bonding network arising due to the explicit solvent molecules are abbreviated with E 0 (X). As example the relative energy of the enol form E (see Scheme 2 of the publication) without considering the influence of the hydrogen bonding network is given as:
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Corresponding computations were performed for all other intermediates depicted in Scheme 2 of the publication. The actual formulas are given below. The resulting energies computed for the compounds 1-11 are summarized in Table 1 of the publication. The s-trans and the s-cis isomers are defined in Figure 5 of the publication.
body_text.section: Description of Model systems and Computational Details

body_text.text: Potential energy curves showing the dependence between addition reaction and proton donor molecule (B3LYP/TZVP//BLYP-RI/TZVP). Energy values are given relative to infinite separated reactants (acrolein-proton-donor complex is treated as one entity to avoid an energy bias due to a newly formed hydrogen bond)
body_text.section: Figure S1

body_text.text: in kJ mol -1 . The respective structures are given in Table S1 . as one entity to avoid energy bias due to newly formed hydrogen bonds) in kJ mol -1 .
body_text.section: Figure S1
r(S---H) r(S---C) in [Å]

FIGREF0.text: influence of the inhibitors on the ketonization step. A base catalyzed ketonization runs across the enolate intermediate E − which is obtained by a proton transfer from the enol oxygen to a base. The enolate intermediate also represents the most important intermediate of addition reactions taking place in quite basic solutions.

FIGREF1.text: PES) to characterize kinetics and thermodynamics of the bond forming process. For each point of the PES r(S--C) and r(S--H) were kept fixed at certain values while all other internal degrees of freedom were optimized. The potential energy surface scans were performed with a resolution of 0.1 Å for the respective grid points. Transition states were identified as maximum points on the potential curves. Frequency analysis of transition states confirmed their nature. The r(O--H) distance (see Figure 2 of the publication) which represents the main coordinate of the protonation of the emerging intermediate had not to be treated as an independent variable. During the optimization of the remaining internal degrees of freedom this coordinate smoothly adjusted for varying distances r(S--C) and r(S--H). The corresponding potential energy surface is depicted in Figure 4 of the publication (upper part). To investigate the influence of r(O--H) in more detail we also computed a two-dimensional PES for which r(O--H) is varied together with the r(S--C). The corresponding PES is also shown in Figure 4 of the publication (lower part).
